citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A female Cavachon puppy id # 157 was keeping her right eye closed. The right eye appeared smaller than the left eye
and the puppy was hesitant to open the eye when handled pulling away from the inspector, indicating a potential pain
response. The condition of this dog’s eye had not been observed by the facility and hence its condition was not
communicated to the veterinarian. The facility must have a method in place to ensure daily observations are conducted on
animal health and that when health issues are noted, the issue is communicated in a timely manner to the veterinarian.
Correct by: Sept 20, 2023

Currently the feeders are not in a location that is easily accessible to the dogs in the enclosure. The feeders are hung
higher up over the sides of the enclosure above the dogs head when standing, which causes the dogs to have to stand on
their back legs to reach the feeder. These feeders need to be lowered to be at a level that allows the dogs to easily reach
the feeders and eat in a normal posture for their wellbeing.

One of the automatic drinker nipples for two dogs was not working and there was no water access in the enclosure. When
water was provided in a bowl, the two dogs identified as “Licorice” and “Fredrick” drank continuously for over two minutes
and Fredrick drank continuously for up to four minutes. Water must be continuously available to the dogs for their health
and wellbeing. The facility must have a method in place to ensure all the automatic drinkers are functioning properly
allowing water to continuously flow or another method of having continuous access to water is in place.
Correct by: Sept 20, 2023
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2) more inspection(s) or by Nov 18, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A female Cavachon puppy id # 157 was keeping her right eye closed. The right eye appeared smaller than the left eye 
and the puppy was hesitant to open the eye when handled pulling away from the inspector, indicating a potential pain 
response. The condition of this dog’s eye had not been observed by the facility and hence its condition was not 
communicated to the veterinarian. The facility must have a method in place to ensure daily observations are conducted on 
animal health and that when health issues are noted, the issue is communicated in a timely manner to the veterinarian. 
Correct by: Sept 20, 2023 
3.9(b) 
   
Feeding 
Currently the feeders are not in a location that is easily accessible to the dogs in the enclosure. The feeders are hung 
higher up over the sides of the enclosure above the dogs head when standing, which causes the dogs to have to stand on 
their back legs to reach the feeder. These feeders need to be lowered to be at a level that allows the dogs to easily reach 
the feeders and eat in a normal posture for their wellbeing. 
3.10(a)  Direct
   
Watering 
One of the automatic drinker nipples for two dogs was not working and there was no water access in the enclosure. When 
water was provided in a bowl, the two dogs identified as “Licorice” and “Fredrick” drank continuously for over two minutes 
and Fredrick drank continuously for up to four minutes. Water must be continuously available to the dogs for their health 
and wellbeing. The facility must have a method in place to ensure all the automatic drinkers are functioning properly 
allowing water to continuously flow or another method of having continuous access to water is in place.  
Correct by: Sept 20, 2023 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within (2) more inspection(s) or by Nov 18, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
